sen.j: 地子交易（じしこうえき）とは、律令制において国司が公田から得た地子稲を中央に上供する際に運搬に便利なように軽貨に交換（売買）すること。
sen.e: Jishi koeki refers to exchanging (selling and buying) of rice as a land tax, which was collected from koden (fields administered directly by a ruler) by a provincial governor under the Ritsuryo system, with light commodities that were easier to carry and submit to the central government.

Jishi koeki refers to the exchange (buying and selling) of rice as a land tax that was collected from koden (fields administered directly by a ruler) by a provincial governor under the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code). Rice was exchanged for light commodities that were easier to carry and submit to the central government.
sen.cmt: (selling and buying)→(buying and selling); added description for "Ritsuryo system"; split into two sentences for easier reading and fixed grammar accordingly
sen.e: Jishi Koeki refers to the exchange (buying and selling) of rice as a land tax that was collected from koden (fields administered directly by a ruler) by a provincial governor under the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code); rice was exchanged for light commodities that were easier to carry and submit to the central government.
sen.cmt: Jishi koeki→表記統一のため、Jishi Koekiとしました。*二文に分かれていますが、原文を分割するのが困難なためセミコロンでつなぎました。

sen.j: 大宝律令の田令逸文にその由来を求めることが可能とされる。
sen.e: The origin of Jishi Koeki was found in itsubun (fragments of a document) about a manager of tax officers under the Taiho Ritsuryo (Taiho Code) system.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The origin of Jishi Koeki was found in an itsubun (fragments of a document) about a manager of tax officers under the Taiho Ritsuryo (Taiho Code) system.
The origin of Jishi Koeki was found in an itsubun (fragments of a document) about a manager of tax officers under the Taiho Ritsuryo (Taiho Code) system.

sen.j: 地子の割当を受けた令制国では、公田から賃租された地子稲を財源として沽価に基づいて絹や鉄などを調達して中央の太政官厨家に送付した。
sen.e: A governor of the province that was required to submit a land tax quota used rice collected from koden as a financial resource to purchase silk or iron based on koka (selling price) and sent this to Daijokan chuke (manager of the kitchen of the Great Council of State) in the central government.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Governors of provinces that were required to submit a land tax quota would use rice collected from koden as a financial resource in order to purchase silk or iron based on koka (selling prices) and sent it to the Daijokan chuke (manager of the kitchen of the Great Council of State) in the central government.
sen.cmt: fixed grammar to read more naturally
sen.e: Governors of provinces that were required to submit a land tax quota would use rice collected from koden as a financial resource in order to purchase silk or iron based on koka (selling prices) and sent it to the Daijokan chuke (manager of the kitchen of the Great Council of State) in the central government.

sen.j: これらは太政官の経費や職員給与に充てられた。
sen.e: The tax was then used to pay Daijokan's expenses or provide for workers.
The tax was then used to pay the expenses of the Daijokan or provide for workers.
sen.cmt: fixed grammar to read more naturally
sen.e: The tax was then used to pay the expenses of the Daijokan or provide for workers.

sen.j: 後に公田そのものが官務を世襲した小槻氏の事実上の所領と化して、そこから地子稲及び地子交易で得られた物資が太政官の経費として捻出されるようになった。
sen.e: Koden later became territories of the Ozuki clan that took over the official position, and tax rice from these territories or commodities obtained through jishi koeki were spent as Daijokan's expenses.

Later on, Koden became territories of the Ozuki clan who took over the official position, and rice taxes from these territories, as well as commodities obtained through Jishi Koeki were spent as expenses for the Daijokan.
